How do innovative people spread their work? In Britain (1547-1851):
 
Published books, etc (2/3)
Teaching, education (34%)
Shared w/ public (31%)
Consulted w/ gov’t, official bodies (15%)
Helped others informally (my favorite; 18%)

(Howes, https://antonhowes.weebly.com/uploads/2/1/0/8/21082490/spread_of_improvement_working_paper.pdf …)pic.twitter.com/BbPRFaoNYN

1032735513004789760.text:
What are characteristics of innovators? In Britain (1547-1851):

Amateurs: ~1/3 innovated in areas w/o requisite training
Talked to each other: 49% joined societies like Royal Society
Evangelized innovation (more than just innovating!)

(Howes, https://antonhowes.weebly.com/uploads/2/1/0/8/21082490/spread_of_improvement_working_paper.pdf …)

1032735511293480960.text:
Should all innovations be patented?

At World Fairs (US/Britain, 1851-1915), 89% were NOT patented
Patents more common when secrecy is ineffective

“Patents...may, in fact, play a relatively limited role in creating incentives to invent”

(Moser, https://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=930241 …)

1032735510421102592.text:
Is it better to give large grants to few elite researchers, or small grants to many?

Large grants don’t lead to larger impact
Small grants, distributed broadly, increase chance of scientific impact

(Fortin & Currie, http://journals.plos.org/plosone/article?id=10.1371/journal.pone.0065263 …)

1032735507711647744.text:
How to design research programs that maximize impact?

Freedom to experiment over longer time (~5 yrs)
Give feedback: help iterate early, often
Fund people! Not projects/deliverables

HHMI produced better outcomes vs. NIH this way

(Azoulay et al http://www.nber.org/papers/w15466 )pic.twitter.com/jIGDtbVdw8

1018568587559211009.text: But I definitely notice the "common sense paradox" in the governance space right now, and perhaps the broader emerging field of so-called cryptoeconomics. Everybody fancies themselves an expert on people. But people are deceptively hard. /fin

1018568586212855809.text: FWIW, I don't think one is harder than the other! I feel like a fish out of water when I talk to my Protocol Labs colleagues, bc they're working on problems I barely understand (and that mutual respect is one of the reasons I love PL ). Each field comes w its own challenges

1018568584602292227.text: Another big problem is the lack of feedback loops. It's hard to know in social science whether you've built a model that works, in the same unequivocal way that you might w "hard" science. Each person in your model is a leaky bucket with hidden motivations and unexpected actions.

1018568583440490496.text: I love studying people because our brains are black boxes, as poorly-understood as the universe. You can only learn the rules by observing actions, and you study this game knowing it can't ever be fully understood.

1018568581917888513.text:
As I finished explaining what I was working on, he interrupted me:

"So you have the hardest job, then."

People are harder than software, he said, because "Unlike bits, atoms have opinions."

1018568579782987777.text: Related anecdote: I met up with a professor a few weeks ago. He asked about my research, and I responded somewhat shyly, as I sometimes do, because I knew he worked with large data sets, whereas I go around talking to people and creeping on mailing lists.

963535044827529216.text: Being able to choose *which* vegetables one can buy, and where you buy them, even on a restricted SNAP debit card, is a huge micro-luxury that reduces the stress of poverty. Being handed a box of government pantry food is dehumanizing and increases stress.

963535043195936768.text: Yet this view (that poor people are entitled to personal agency) is surprisingly unpopular, and the only reason I see for pushback is because we secretly believe poor people deserve their fate.

963535042407313408.text: One of the worst things about being poor is feeling a lack of agency. Poor people have wants - not just needs - like any other human. We need to design policies that account for stress management and dignity, not just dollars in and out.

963535041534902272.text: Beyond that, my biggest takeaway from being on SNAP is that there are psychological benefits to receiving benefits in "cash" (again: restricted), rather than being handed a box of food.

963535040511528960.text: I'm not sure what problem this proposal is trying to solve, because as @JShahryar explains, there are already strict guidelines as to what you can/can't buy with a SNAP debit card.

963535039186141186.text: Food stamps are incredibly misunderstood. I once mentioned my experience on SNAP in a blog post I wrote ~5 years ago, could not believe the backlash I got.https://twitter.com/JShahryar/status/963520227735519232 …
